persona.name: María Guadalupe López Juárez

occupation.title: Smallholder farmer and occasional market vendor
occupation.organization: Self-employed / communal ejido assembly member for land work rotations
occupation.description: María is primarily responsible for a 0.5–1 hectare family milpa where she cultivates maize, beans and squash, and a small shaded coffee parcel (intercropped). She manages most day-to-day tasks: planting, weeding, harvesting, seed saving, and basic post-harvest processing. She coordinates seasonal labor with neighbors and family, organizes communal 'faenas' (work parties), and participates in the ejido assembly decisions regarding grazing, communal terraces and seed distribution. In the dry season she compiles and mends nets and tools, sells embroidered blouses and woven belts at the weekly municipal market, and sometimes does day labor (cosecha) on larger farms or in nearby towns to earn cash. Her responsibilities include household food preparation, childcare for grandchildren when needed, and ensuring traditional ceremonies are observed. Skills relevant to her occupation include knowledge of milpa cycles, pest identification, seed selection (criollo seeds), basic coffee sorting, bartering at markets, and organizing cooperative labor.

persona.residence: San Pedro El Pinal (near Comitán), Chiapas — small Tzeltal/Tzotzil-influenced communal village, rural highland area
persona.education: Completed primary school in the village (6 years). Attended occasional adult literacy and numeracy workshops run by a local NGO in her 40s. Speaks Tzeltal (native) fluently and Spanish as a second language with rural southern Mexican accent; reads simple Spanish but is more comfortable with spoken communication. No formal secondary or vocational qualification.
long_term_goals: Keep the family's milpa (maize/bean/squash plot) productive and pass knowledge of traditional agriculture to at least one grandchild.
Ensure access to medical care for herself and her older husband without incurring crippling debt.
Strengthen communal ties so that the village maintains its festivals, language use and mutual aid.
Accumulate a small emergency fund (cash saved from remittances/market sales) to cover unexpected funerals or medical needs.
See at least two of her children visit the house more often and have their children learn traditional songs and dances.
Maintain the family home and continue making and selling a small amount of handicraft at the municipal market.
persona.style: Warm, soft-spoken but direct; uses a mix of Tzeltal proverbs and colloquial Spanish when telling stories. Uses respectful forms ("doña", "compañero/a", "usted") with outsiders, more familiar diminutives with family. Typical speech includes pauses to find words in Spanish, frequent use of hand gestures and pointing to the ground when discussing crops; laughs quietly and inclines her head when amused. Dresses practically: embroidered huipil or simple blouse, long skirt or sturdy trousers, rubber sandals or low boots for the field, colorful shawl for ceremonies. Keeps hair braided or in a bun. Mannerisms: wipes hands on apron before eating, offers tamales to visitors, insists visitors sit and drink coffee, crosses herself before meals and when starting any communal work. In public assemblies she speaks with measured calm, often deferring to elders but also assertive when land or health issues are at stake. Technology use is light: owns a basic cellphone for calls and receiving remittances via a younger relative; gets information from radio (community transmitter) and occasional visits from mobile health teams. When political or sensitive topics arise, she lowers her voice and uses indirect phrasing or proverbial stories to express disagreement.

traits: Deeply communal — prioritizes family and village welfare over individual gain.
Practical and resourceful — finds low-cost solutions and reuses materials.
Patient with children and livestock, but brusque when rules of reciprocity are broken.
Emotionally resilient — has endured migration, loss, and crop failures and continues daily work.
Traditionalist in values — wants to preserve ceremonies, language and gendered customs, while pragmatic about small changes that bring cash.
Curious about small improvements (e.g., a better maize variety or a more efficient stove) but skeptical of outsiders' promises.
Religiously syncretic — Catholic practice intertwined with indigenous rituals and respect for nature/spirits.
Holds grudges toward those who take advantage of the poor but forgives over time when genuine reconciliation occurs.
Nurturing and protective — fiercely defends grandchildren and the remaining family land.
Modest pride — reluctant to boast about her skills, but accepts praise with a soft smile.

interests: Preserving and teaching traditional songs and prayers sung in Tzeltal.
Attending and preparing for the patron-saint fiesta and household blessings.
Learning small agricultural techniques suggested by trusted extension agents (e.g., contour planting).
Cooking traditional foods (tamales, pozol, fresh tortillas) using family recipes.
Weaving simple belts and embroidering blouses with floral patterns taught by her mother.
Listening to the local radio station for news about weather, market prices, and community announcements.
Socializing at the weekly municipal market — trading goods, sharing gossip, checking on relatives.
Keeping the household medicinal chest with herbs and recipes for common ailments.
Receiving visits from godchildren and sharing recipes or sewing tips.
Keeping photographs of family members who migrated to the U.S. and pointing them out to visitors.
likes: Freshly ground coffee in the morning brewed with a cloth filter and panela.
Handmade tortillas and warm tamales wrapped in banana leaves.
Sunrise walks to check the milpa and the state of young plants.
The smell of earth after the first rain (la primera lluvia).
Sitting at the market under the awning, exchanging news and small gossip.
The pattern of a well-embroidered blouse; she likes bright blues and reds.
When her eldest grandson sings a school song in Tzeltal.
Candles lit at home altars during All Saints and the village fiesta.
Receiving remittances that allow small investments (buying a sack of fertilizer).
The practical sturdiness of rubber sandals for rainy work.
dislikes: Politicians who promise and do not deliver; empty speeches.
When young people forget traditional obligations and don't attend communal work.
Heavy-handed outsiders who scold local customs or offer impractical technologies.
Neighbours who let their animals run loose and damage her plot.
Her husband's occasional drinking binges that reduce household cash.
Expensive goods that break after a short time.
Intermittent electricity that ruins stored food or prevents simple evening tasks.
food_preferences: Breakfast: fresh tortillas, black coffee, sometimes eggs or leftover frijoles.
Lunch: tamal or rice with beans, sometimes a little chili salsa from a family recipe.
Snacks: roasted maize, panela pieces, tamarind sweets bought at market.
Favorites during festivals: mole (a small portion), pozole shared among neighbors.
Avoids over-sweetened beverages; prefers water and coffee.
Prefers seasonal fruit — guava, papaya, plantain when available.
Cooks with lard sparingly and favors vegetable oil when trying to save resources.
media_and_technology: Listens to community radio for local news and prayers in the early morning.
Owns a basic mobile phone used mainly for calls and occasional picture messages from children abroad.
Does not use social media regularly; a younger niece sometimes posts photos for the family.
Reads printed flyers or notices posted on the communal kiosk about assembly dates.

beliefs: Healthcare should be accessible to everyone; people should not be bankrupted by a single illness.
The government must play a role in providing medicine and visiting clinics to remote villages.
Traditional healers and medicinal plants have real value and should be respected alongside doctors.
Education is important for children, but the immediate need to earn money sometimes forces them to miss school.
Land given to communities (ejido) is sacred and must be protected from outsiders and companies.
Communal work (faena) and mutual aid are the glue that keeps the village alive.
Remittances are lifelines but create complex family dynamics and responsibilities.
Big political parties often promise benefits but rarely follow through; still, social programs help and should be defended.
Corruption is widespread in higher levels of government; local leaders often can't be trusted fully.
Catholic practices bring comfort and social cohesion, but indigenous offerings and rites are essential for good harvests.
Women should be respected for their role in managing households and agriculture; they deserve access to health services.
Young people need opportunities at home; migration should be a choice, not a necessity.
The climate is changing (less predictable rains); adaptation is necessary and elders' knowledge is useful.
Seeds from grandparents (criollo) carry resilience and identity; hybrid seeds are useful sometimes but risk dependence.
Children should learn the language and songs of the village to maintain identity.
Debt to local tiendas and informal lenders traps families; cooperative saving is better.
Politics at the municipal level is personal — neighbor against neighbor — so one must be cautious with alliances.
Public infrastructure (roads, electricity, water) improves life but often arrives late and with opaque costs.
Government health campaigns (vaccinations, mosquito spraying) are helpful but sometimes poorly communicated.
Gender roles are changing slowly: some women take leadership in assemblies, but it's still often difficult.
Youth education is the best protection against exploitation by labor intermediaries or traffickers.
The Church should help with social services but must not replace communal autonomy.
Community assemblies should be transparent and include women’s voices.
Language preservation is a political act as well as cultural — losing the tongue means losing memory.
Foreign NGOs can be helpful, but projects must be designed with local people, not imposed.
Public pensions for elders are a crucial safety net, yet many elders are excluded by paperwork problems.
Justice is slow; personal mediation and ritual reconciliation are often more practical than courts.
The idea of 'progress' should not erase traditional knowledge about soils, weather signs, and seed saving.
Family obligations (godparenthood, debt of gratitude) are central to social life and decision-making.
The village must balance openness to small improvements (stoves, solar lamps) with protection of customs.
skills: Extensive knowledge of milpa cycles: when to plant maize, beans and squash by observing moon and rains.
Seed selection and saving of criollo maize adapted to local slope and shade.
Basic coffee harvesting and sorting; knowledge of shade trees that improve bean quality.
Hand embroidery and simple weaving skills for making belts and blouse trims.
Traditional cooking: nixtamalizing maize, tortilla making by hand, preparing tamales and local stews.
Herbal medicine knowledge: preparing poultices, teas, and topical salves for common ailments.
Basic bookkeeping for household purchases and small sales at market.
Negotiation and bartering skills used at the municipal market.
Leadership in organizing communal work and ritual preparations for local festivals.
Childcare and early childhood practices rooted in extended-family support.
Simple carpentry and fence repair using local wood and a machete.
Ability to prepare the family altar for feast days and organize offerings correctly.
Listening and mediation skills used in resolving neighbor disputes during assemblies.
Basic Spanish literacy sufficient to read official notices and sign simple documents, often assisted by a relative.
Ability to navigate informal remittance systems via a traveling relative or a local intermediary.

general: Starts most conversations by asking after family and health before discussing other matters.
Offers guests coffee, then tamales or tortillas; hospitality is extended even when resources are scarce.
Uses proverbs and short stories when making a point in assemblies ('el maíz no se compara...').
Keeps a small notebook with names, debts, and dates of market sales hidden in the kitchen drawer.
When stressed about money she hums a prayer while sorting seeds or mending clothes.
Always participates in the morning communal prayer during the village feast week.
Prefers face-to-face communication; avoids heated public confrontations but will speak firmly in private if necessary.

morning: Wakes around 5:00–5:30 AM, lights a small stove, prepares coffee and wakes the household for chores.
Checks the milpa, inspects young plants for pests, does light weeding and waters where needed.
Feeds chickens and checks any small livestock; collects eggs for breakfast or sale.
Tends to the home hearth: makes fresh tortillas and prepares a modest breakfast.
Listens to short radio bulletin for weather and municipal notices while preparing children/grandchildren for school.
workday: Spends midmorning in the fields with a machete and hoe, doing the physically demanding tasks when sun is gentle.
Returns mid-day for lunch and a short rest; performs ritual blessing over food when relatives are absent.
Afternoons are for lighter tasks: mending nets, sorting coffee beans, embroidering, or attending an assembly.
Once a week attends the municipal market to sell a few embroidered items, a sack of maize, or a basket of beans.
Uses an afternoon visit with neighbors to exchange seeds, gossip, and necessary favors like childcare.
evening: Prepares a simple family dinner and ensures grandchildren wash hands before eating.
Sits briefly by the doorway to keep watch of the street and greet passersby.
Prays softly and lights a candle at the home altar for deceased relatives.
Mends clothing by lamplight or tells grandchildren stories in Tzeltal before they sleep.
weekend_and_festival: On market day travels to the town center early and returns with trade goods, sometimes accompanied by children.
Participates in extended feast celebrations that can last several days, preparing special foods and decorating the chapel.
Goes to family lands for extended milling and collective work during planting/harvest seasons.
Spends time teaching grandchildren songs, recipes, and how to use simple tools.

physical: General stamina suited to daily agricultural labor but slower mobility than in youth; occasional breathlessness on steep slopes.
Early-stage hypertension diagnosed during a mobile clinic visit; takes medication irregularly due to cost and stockouts at the health post.
Chronic lower back pain from years of bending and carrying loads; manages with herbal compresses and occasional ibuprofen.
Partial tooth loss and dental pain; limited access to dental care leads to reliance on herbal rinses and occasional tooth extractions by itinerant dentist.
Mild presbyopia (needs reading glasses) and occasional watery eyes; no formal cataract surgery due to travel costs.
No diagnosis of diabetes but watches diet due to family history and irregular checkups.
Low body mass index compared to urban standards but not acutely malnourished; caloric intake varies seasonally.
mental_and_social: Resilient mental state overall; occasional anxiety and sadness tied to children's migration and money worries.
Uses prayer, communal rituals and social visits to cope with grief and stress.
Has experienced bereavement (loss of a sister and two neighbors in past decade) and participated in extended mourning rituals.
Occasional insomnia during planting season due to worry about crop failure and loan repayment.
Strong social support from women neighbors and godmothers who form an informal safety net.
healthcare_access: Relies on the rural health post which has intermittent staffing; travels to municipal clinic when serious.
Uses a mix of biomedical services and traditional healers (curanderos) depending on the ailment and cost.
Has participated in vaccination campaigns for grandchildren and occasional government-check mobile clinics for measurement of blood pressure.

relationships.name: José Adrián López (husband)
relationships.description: Works alongside her in the milpa and does occasional day labor. Has a quiet temper and drinks sometimes; they have a long marriage with cooperative but occasionally tense economic discussions.

relationships.name: Héctor López (eldest son)
relationships.description: Lives and works in southern California; sends remittances intermittently. Married with two children. Maintains phone contact; visited home twice in the past five years.

relationships.name: Rosa María López (daughter)
relationships.description: Lives in the nearby municipal seat with a small kiosk selling prepared foods; helps with grandchildren and occasionally helps at the market.

relationships.name: Ana (granddaughter)
relationships.description: Attends primary school; often helps with chores and shows interest in embroidery — María hopes to teach her.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen (neighbor and sister in faena)
relationships.description: An older woman who coordinates the women's kitchen during fiestas and is a sounding board for María's decisions.

relationships.name: Community assembly members
relationships.description: Group of men and women who elect decisions for the ejido; María attends and sometimes leads talks on health and women's care.

relationships.name: Local parish priest
relationships.description: Performs baptisms and leads feast celebrations; María respects him but also integrates indigenous rites alongside Catholic ceremonies.

relationships.name: Younger niece (Maribel)
relationships.description: Works in the municipal office and occasionally helps María send/receive money transfers and takes photos for social media.

other_facts: Was born in the same village; her full childhood was spent learning household arts, agricultural tasks and ceremonies from her mother and grandmother.
Her name 'Guadalupe' reflects the Catholic syncretism common in the region — she is proud of the dual identity of being Tzeltal and Catholic.
Remembers a major drought when she was 12 that required families to share seed and food; the memory shapes her aversion to waste.
Is godmother to three children in neighboring families and participates in godparent obligations like lending modest cash at baptisms and funerals.
Has a small altar corner in the kitchen with a framed Virgin of Guadalupe picture, incense ash and a woven ribbon given by her mother.
Learnt basic Spanish at school but prefers Tzeltal when speaking about crops, dreams and proverbs.
Owns a battered notebook where she records birthdays, who owes whom food or work favors, and the times her children visited.
Has a scar on her left forearm from a machete accident decades ago while clearing a new plot; the scar still tightens in cold weather.
Participated in a coop microcredit program five years ago that offered seed money; repaid late once but rebuilt trust through extra market sales.
Once negotiated successfully with a middleman to get a slightly better price for a coffee lot by bringing a neighbor as witness.
Saw two of her siblings migrate to coastal towns in their youth; one returned ill and later died — memory reinforces caution about migration risks.
Knows how to prepare a poultice from plantain leaves that reduces swelling and uses it for her grandchildren's scraped knees.
Her eldest son Héctor calls every few weeks and asks about maize prices; she uses the calls to ask for small help like buying medicine.
Has a personal recipe for a mild chili salsa that everyone in the village recognizes as 'la salsa de doña María'.
Belongs to a small women's circle that organizes contributions for communal cooking during feast weeks and funerals.
Once organized a small collective sale of embroidered goods at the municipal fair, which brought in a week's worth of cash income spread across members.
Sells small quantities of surplus maize and beans at the market and uses proceeds for household soap, medicine and school supplies.
Remembers the exact years when roads were first paved nearby; this opened access to the municipal clinic but also increased prices.
Has an informal agreement with a neighbor to look after each other's houses when someone travels to a nearby town.
Is wary of formal bank accounts due to paperwork complexity; prefers cash saved in a hidden tin and cooperative savings kept by the women's group.
Taught her daughter to make tortillas by pressing by hand and still demonstrates the technique to curious visitors.
Participated in a government health fair that offered blood-pressure screening; this is where she first learned she had hypertension.
Once organized a small protest with other women when a local empresario tried to fence communal land — the protest led to a municipal mediation.
Keeps an old photograph of her wedding day pinned inside a small chest, showing the simple embroidered dress and a crowded chapel.
Was involved in a negotiation with a seed company representative; learned to ask for references from other villages before agreeing to buy seeds.
Has a neighbor who runs a small moto-taxi and occasionally gives her and José rides to the market for a small fee.
Values frank advice from elders; when in doubt she visits Doña Carmen to discuss decisions about children or money.
Believes in planting ceremonies — she sprinkles a few kernels of maize and prays to bless the new plot.
Has a childhood memory of her grandmother teaching using stars and seasons instead of a calendar — she passes those stories on to grandchildren.
Once borrowed money to pay for a birthing complication for a sister; the debt was repaid in labor and shared maize over two years.
Remembers a local flood that took three days of cooperative work to rebuild a footbridge — shows how infrastructure failures directly affect life.
Enjoys small luxuries when possible: a bar of locally made soap, a new ribbon for the hair or a small package of imported cookies for grandchildren.
Keeps a small stash of photocopied identity documents in a sealed plastic bag to avoid problems when children need paperwork for school or migration.
Has a modest dream of one grandchild learning to read fluently in both Spanish and Tzeltal so the family's memory can be recorded.
Was once visited by a university anthropology student collecting oral histories; she enjoyed telling stories but expected some reciprocity for the time spent.
Knows which government official to contact in the municipal seat for small infrastructure issues, but only through word-of-mouth recommendations.
Feels proud when her embroidery is complimented by city visitors and keeps a drawer with her best pieces reserved for special sales.
Often wakes before dawn on festival mornings to prepare food, believing that early work honors ancestors and ensures a good event.
Sees the local women’s group as a political and social schooling ground — through it she learned to sign her name and to count sales.
Holds a small superstition that if a dog howls at night near the house, relatives abroad will call with news soon — she smiles when it happens.
Has been interviewed once by a public-health team about maternal care practices and suggested they include traditional midwives in outreach programs.
